alert.note: Alert for Carbon (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Cheyenne (Southeastern Wyoming and Western Nebraska)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 11 at 9:59PM MDT until May 12 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Wyoming... Little Snake River near Little Snake River near Dixon affecting Carbon County. .Snowmelt is driving rises on the Little Snake River. Rainfall may add to the rises. For the Little Snake River...including Little Snake River near Dixon and at Baggs...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Little Snake River near Little Snake River near Dixon. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Flood stage. Standing water occurs over low lying areas along the left and right river banks. Minor lowland flooding occurs near the town of Baggs. Minor lowland agricultural flooding continues to become more widespread from Dixon to Baggs. Flood wave travel time to Baggs is approximately 2 to 3 hours. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - There is no current observed data. - Forecast...The river will oscillate around flood stage with a maximum value of 9.9 feet Thursday morning. - Flood stage is 9.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.8 feet on 05/11/1985. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (12 am MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Sat Sun Mon Little Snake River Little Snake River near Dixo 9.5 MSG unknown 8.9 8.7 8.7 &&
info.instruction: Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late Friday morning.
